2. Guided by the issues themselves.
By “ontology” we do not mean a specific philosophical discipline that can be lined up with other disciples like epistemology, ethics, and so forth. This book is not trying to meet the established standards of any discipline of philosophy. The only standard we follow is to remain focused on our first-person experience of the “things themselves,” ◊
(1) “The things themselves” (die Sachen selbst,” cf. Husserl, Logische Untersuchungen II, 1, p. 6) are both what shows up in experience and how it shows up—in German, both das Seiende and das Sein des Seienden.
(2) When Heidegger uses the phrase in the singular (“die Sache selbst,” the thing itself) he is referring not to things in their being but to the clearing held open by and as ex-sistence, which is what makes possible the experience of things in their being.
Close
which is an axiom that applies to all sciences and disciplines.
